ATOFINA Chemicals values the safety of our employees and area residents.  We are committed to responsible chemical processing and handling.  As an example of our commitment, the plant and the Paper, Allied-Chemical & Energy Workers Union, Local 6-0591 have joined together to implement the Triangle of Prevention (TOP) Program to further enhance safety, health, and protection of the environment.
ATOFINA Chemicals takes pride in our commitment to protect the environment.  We are dedicated to continuous reduction of waste, and have a comprehensive program called AWARE (ATOFINA Waste And Release Elimination) designed to promote recycling and waste minimization.  We have substantially reduced waste and emissions in recent years.

ATOFINA Chemicals also participates in the American Chemistry Council  Responsible Care? initiative.  Through Responsible Care, our company and industry demonstrate a continuing commitment to health, safety, and the environment.


Facility Identification and Regulated Substances in Covered Processes

The ATOFINA Chemicals Riverview Plant is located at 17168 West Jefferson Avenue, Riverview, Michigan.  The facility manufactures industrial chemicals, primarily amines and acids.  Our products are used to produce a wide variety of products including photographic products, pharmaceuticals, electronics, cosmetics, paints, cleaners, tires, water treatment products, and agricultural chemicals.

Certain substances used and/or produced within the facility are regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.

Ammonia, chlorine, dimethylamine, ethylene oxide, ethyl mercaptan, furan, isopropylamine, methylamine, methyl mercaptan, and propylene oxide are used as process feedstocks.  Monoethylamine is produced at the facility and is also used as a process feedstock.  These substances are present at or above the minimum threshold for RMP applicability.

Hazard Assessment

The EPA regulat

ions specify that facilities include in their RMP an analysis of a worst case accident (one where all safety systems fail at the same time) for listed toxic chemicals and for listed flammables.  The regulations also specify that alternative accidents (ones that are more realistic) be included.

Hazard Assessment - Worst Case Scenario

The toxic worst-case accidental release scenario is a catastrophic failure of a chlorine railcar containing 180,000 pounds.

The flammable worst-case accidental release scenario is a catastrophic failure of a dimethylamine railcar containing 167,000 pounds.  This quantity was assumed to be released instantly in the worst case scenario resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.

It should be noted that the worst-case scenarios are extremely unlikely events.  For a worst-case scenario to occur, all of the following would have to happen:
C Everything held in the largest vessel is released;
C All of the chemical in the vessel is released very quickly over a ten minute period;
C All safety controls fail at once;
C There is no strong wind or moderate breeze to dilute vapors;  and
C No mitigating action is taken.

This Risk Management Plan includes information on mitigation and prevention measures implemented by ATOFINA Chemicals to reduce the risk of these types of events.

 
Worst-Case Release Mitigation Measures

The multiple layers of preventive measures make it very unlikely that a complete failure of a  chlorine or dimethylamine railcar will occur.  In addition, in the unlikely event that a release occurs, ATOFINA Chemicals has an array of mitigation measures to reduce any potential impacts.

Active mitigation systems cannot be considered in modeling worst-case scenario impacts, but the significant investment that ATOFINA Chemicals has made in active mitigation measures should effectively reduce the risk associated with an RMP incident.  These include:

C Chlorine leak detectors at the chlorine railroad unloading station to provide early war

ning of  a potential release;

C Chlorine unloading is under continuous observation by operators to provide early warning of a potential release;

C Chlorine and dimethylamine railcars are equipped with remote operated valve actuators to provide a prompt shutoff to the railcar in the event of a release downstream from the railcar valves; and

C Chlorine and dimethylamine tanks and piping are frequently inspected by operators and supervisors to detect potential problems.


Hazardous Assessment - Alternative Release Scenario

One alternative scenario for each regulated toxic substance was modeled in the hazard assessment.  A description of each of these scenarios and the modeled distance of potential impacts follows:  The Alternative Release Scenario for anhydrous ammonia is a railcar unloading line leak  The Alternative Release Scenario for chlorine is railcar unloading line hose rupture.  The Alternative Release Scenario for ethylene oxide is a tank overfill. The Alternative Release Scenario for furan is a tank truck unloading line leak. The Alternative Release Scenario for methyl mercaptan is a railcar unloading line leak. The Alternative Release Scenario for propylene oxide is a railcar unloading line leak.

One alternative scenario representing all regulated flammable substances was selected and modeled in the hazard assessment.  A description follows:  The Alternative Scenario selected is for a release of dimethylamine from a railcar unloading line failure causing a vapor cloud explosion..

The Alternative Release Scenarios described are somewhat more likely than a Worst-Case Scenario, but are still unlikely events.  The Risk Management Plan includes information on mitigation and prevention measures implemented by ATOFINA Chemicals to reduce the risk of these types of events.

The emergency response plan includes procedures for notifying civil authorities and the public in the event of an incident.  The plan also includes documentation of proper first-aid and medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures; procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection and testing; a description of the training program for employees in relevant emergency response procedures; and procedures for review and update of the emergency response plan to reflect changes at the facility, and to ensure that employees are informed of these changes.

ATOFINA Chemicals also has an on-site Emergency Response Team which performs regular emergency response drills and critiques of the drills.  Some drills are done with the local fire and police departments.  ATOFINA Chemicals on-site emergency equipment includes a fully equipped  fire truck with fire fighting foam capability and a 2,000 gallon vacuum truck for quickly collecting spills.  There are first-aid trained personnel on each shift and a Plant Nurse on-site on the day shift.  The ATOFINA Chemicals Emergency Response Team receives over 40 hours of annual emergency response training.


Clean Air Act Amendments Title V Permit Status

The ATOFINA Chemicals Riverview Plant has applied for a Title V Air Permit.  The permit has not yet been issued.  Therefore, Section 1., element 12.C. of the Risk Management Plan (CAA Title V) has been checked, but no air permit ID number has been entered.
